awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Self-Centering Pendulum Shear Walls in Buildings via Nonlinear Elastic Kinematics
awd_abstract_narration:
A grand challenge in structural engineering is to develop building systems that can resist loads from extreme natural hazards, such as hurricanes or earthquakes, with minimum or no damage. Such building systems could enable immediate occupancy and minimum economic losses after an extreme event, contributing to continued national prosperity and welfare. Progress has been made towards addressing this challenge with the development of unbonded, post-tensioned, shear walls (UPSWs) in buildings; yet limiting issues for designing such shear walls remain. This research will explore an innovative concept for structural shear walls to resist lateral loads in buildings and perform damage free during an extreme event. The concept consists of coupled, unbonded, post-tensioned, reinforced concrete walls that interact with the foundation via a curved surface. Lateral deformations will be accommodated through a pendulum-type motion as the wall slides along the bottom curved surface. Lateral resistance will be provided by friction along the curved surface and the vertical unbonded post-tensioned cables. The post-tensioned cables also will help restore the wall to its initial configuration. Energy dissipation of these coupled pendulum walls will be provided by incorporating connecting devices that use elastic buckling and release accumulated elastic energy during the walls' deformations. The system response thus will leverage the resulting deformations rather than trying to constrain them, as in traditional systems. The result will be new technology related to the design of damage-free structural building systems, and a new way of thinking about leveraging system geometry and deformations for enhanced resilient and sustainable buildings. Parallel to the research effort will be complementary educational and outreach components, including the training of two Ph.D. students, research experiences for undergraduate students, a project website with tutorials and research findings for undergraduate and graduate students and practitioners, and outreach activities for middle and high school students.  The tutorials, as well as data from this project, also will be made publicly available in the NSF-supported Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure Data Depot (https://www.designsafe-ci.org). 

The core idea of this research is that of a new design philosophy envisioned to be unrestricted by traditional material failure limit states. This philosophy will be verified through a new concept for coupled UPSWs. The material response limitations of rocking UPSWs will be addressed by harnessing the nonlinear kinematic behavior resulting from coupled system deformations. Thus, the project objective is to develop the enabling theory and technology for a new concept of UPSWs that can perform damage free and unrestricted by material failure limit states. This objective will be achieved through two unique and complementary features: (1) individual walls gliding along a circular path with no separation at the footing interface, and (2) continuous energy dissipation via devices with controllable elastic instabilities along vertical wall joints. This concept will be designated as a pendulum UPSW system, as it rotates about a fixed point on the wall. The approach to be followed will be to characterize the in-plane response of pendulum UPSWs as viable lateral load resisting elements, develop and characterize the use of elastic meta-materials and meta-structures for dissipating energy via elastic instabilities, and characterize the response of pendulum UPSWs coupled with elastic multi-stable structures as connectors. A combination of analytical, numerical (finite element), and experimental methods will be used. This research will lead to the fundamental integration of system geometry and deformations for the design of lateral load resisting structures that are resilient and sustainable. The study will promote new design concepts that harness deformations for optimal performance rather than performance objectives set to target material limit states. The research also will contribute to the use of nonlinear elastic instabilities in large-scale structural systems. Theory and methods related to damage-free structural systems, friction models, and elastic energy dissipation devices will also be advanced.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Summary of Outcomes: 

This project focused on developing self-centering pendulum shear walls to enhance the seismic resilience of buildings. Traditional shear walls, crucial for resisting lateral seismic forces, often sustain damage and require costly repairs. The innovative design introduced here features a circular base profile, allowing the wall to glide rather than uplift under seismic loads. Energy is dissipated through friction at the base interface, eliminating the need for additional dampers or bars. This design enables the wall to pivot like a pendulum, improving safety and cost-effectiveness by ensuring the wall remains damage-free after extreme seismic events.

Intellectual Merit: 

 At the core of this project was the development of a self-centering pendulum shear wall system that combines nonlinear elastic kinematics with an innovative circular base geometry. This system was designed to respond to lateral loads in a way that allows the wall to glide rather than uplift or tip over, which is a common issue with conventional rocking shear walls. In the context of this work lateral loads are those generated by earthquakes. By using a circular base profile, the wall can pivot about a single point, absorbing seismic energy through friction at the base interface. This approach ensures that the system remains damage-free and returns to its original position after an event, without requiring repairs or the replacement of energy dissipation components.

Key findings from this research include:

Geometric Optimization: The introduction of a circular base profile was found to be critical in maintaining continuous contact between the wall and the foundation during seismic events, preventing damage to materials and eliminating issues like concrete crushing and tendon yielding that can occur in traditional systems.

Energy Dissipation through Friction: By relying on frictional energy dissipation at the base, the system eliminates the need for additional dampers or external components that are typically used to absorb seismic energy. This innovative approach not only improves the system’s cost-effectiveness but also reduces maintenance needs and environmental impact over time.

Nonlinear Behavior Modeling: this work advanced the modeling of friction mechanism that are pressure dependent. This new model builds on previous friction models, and offers new insights into how friction dependent systems behave under extreme loading conditions. These findings help improve the accuracy of design models for buildings subjected to seismic forces.

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts of this research extend well beyond the field of structural engineering and into the safety, economic stability, and sustainability of communities. This research addresses critical societal needs, particularly in earthquake-prone regions:

Enhanced Safety and Community Resilience: The pendulum shear wall system ensures that buildings can maintain structural integrity and functionality during and after an earthquake. Critical infrastructure such as hospitals, schools, and emergency facilities can continue to operate, reducing the risk to human life and enhancing overall community resilience in the aftermath of natural disasters.

Economic Benefits: One of the major advantages of this system is its ability to reduce repair costs following extreme events. By avoiding the need for expensive structural repairs, the system provides long-term cost savings for building owners, municipalities, and insurers. Furthermore, the ability to quickly restore operational capacity following a disaster minimizes economic losses by reducing downtime and operational disruptions.

Environmental Sustainability: The self-centering pendulum shear wall system is inherently more sustainable than traditional systems because it does not rely on sacrificial components like energy dampers that must be replaced after each event. This reduces material waste, conserves resources, and supports greener construction practices that help reduce the environmental footprint of building projects.

Workforce Development: The project has also contributed to the training and development of young engineers. Several students were involved in hands-on research, from testing the shear wall system to analyzing the data using cutting-edge techniques like Digital Image Correlation (DIC). This experience provided students with valuable skills in structural testing, data analysis, and advanced modeling techniques—all of which are critical for developing innovative solutions in the construction and engineering fields.

Conclusion

The outcomes of this award can greatly advance the field of earthquake engineering by providing a novel solution for making buildings safer and more resilient in the face of extreme seismic events. The pendulum shear wall system represents a major step forward in designing damage-resistant and energy-efficient infrastructure. By optimizing geometric design, integrating friction-based energy dissipation, and utilizing nonlinear elastic kinematics, this technology offers a sustainable and cost-effective alternative to traditional seismic resistance systems.

Moving forward, this research will continue to be refined and integrated into industry practice. Collaboration with construction professionals and government agencies will be key to adopting this system in real-world applications. The system’s potential to save lives, reduce economic losses, and promote sustainable building practices makes it a promising technology for future infrastructure development.
